forecast.review: Both forecasters largely restate the 338Canada signal and the Ontario/Quebec advantage. Forecaster 2 leans heavily on the model’s 188–196 range and argues that a lower probability would be dismissive of a robust model; I don’t fully agree—model uncertainty and correlated regional polling errors can still produce tail outcomes below 172 without “dismissing” the model. Forecaster 3 usefully highlights the 36% increase in advance turnout as a source of uncertainty and emphasizes the limited time left, which I find directionally persuasive but not decisive. Neither adds new quantitative evidence on the distribution tails (e.g., the model’s probability of <172) or the magnitude of regional error required, but both make a fair point that a 16–24 seat buffer this close to E-day reduces the likelihood of a miss below 172 absent a late shock.
forecast.rationale: My prior (72%) already weighted the 338Canada projection and ON/QC vote efficiency against risks from late movement, regional polling error (especially Quebec/Bloc dynamics and Ontario’s 905), and turnout composition uncertainty. After considering the deliberation, I put slightly more weight on the size of the current seat buffer and the short timeline, which together imply that falling below 172 likely requires either a non-trivial late swing or a concentrated polling miss in key regions. I still temper the probability because (1) the cited 188–196 looks like a narrow most-likely band rather than a full credible interval; (2) Canada’s regionalized errors can flip many marginal ridings at once; (3) elevated advance turnout raises uncertainty about voter composition. Net: modest upward adjustment, not all the way to the mid-80s given tail risks that a single model and toplines may understate.
